result.execSummary:
The defendant Kawane A. Weaver was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Delivery of Methamphetamine(<=3g) [Modifiers: Repeater, Second and Subsequent Offense], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.
  • Possess w/ Intent-Methamphetamine(>10-50g) [Modifiers: Repeater, Second or Subsequent Offense], a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(e)3.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Motion Hearing 2/26/18
Copy of notice of appeal mailed with transmittal to Court of Appeals along with a copy of the court record history.
Denying Post-Conviction Motion

Case called at 1:36 p.m.    Defendant Kawane A. Weaver in court with Attorney Leonard D. Kachinsky.  Defendant Kawane A. Weaver in custody.  Peter J. Rindal appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Here on defendant's post-conviction motion.  Court has reviewed both defendant's , Attorney Kachinsky and DDA Rindal's responses.  Defense has subpoened Attorney Tom Starr, not sure why he's not here.  Court does not believe Attorney Starr's appearance is necessary because he does not believe plea agreement was not violated. No manfest in justice.  Plea deal was exactly what was ordered by Judge Lenz.  
1).  Plea should be withdrawn because State did not comply with plea agreement
       Court does not believe there was a breach of agreement
2).  Withdraw plea and have resentenced
       This was the plea agreement and that is what happened.  Motion denied
3).  Motion to suppress
       Facts presented by Attorney Kachinsky in his response do not have cause to reconsider suppression issue.  Motion denied
Attorney Kachinsky will prepare an order for the Courts review.
Dated 2/26/18 from Atty Len Kachinsky to Court regarding post conviction motion
